p: A second example relates to the technically and ethically complex processes used to assign monetary values to “invaluable assets”, such as human life and health. Currently, different models use different estimates to determine the valuation of a human life, such as an individual’s willingness to pay, or national income levels. This has resulted in some economic assessments valuing the lives of individuals in richer countries more than the lives of individuals in poorer countries [ 78]. Such approaches reaffirm that intra-generational inequity remains a key issue in the development of climate change policies.
